An outstanding example of a real good game. Very intimate, touching story about friendship and loyalty, in some ways it's very hearthwarming but it also doesn't conceal the most dark parts of the human soul. This story will have an impact on everyone but only the most callous cold people. Wisely chosen soundtrack that greatly succeeds at creating a feeling of all the game events. The graphic is stylized but it still able to create astonishing images. Gameplay is very calm and doesn't require player to rush it through, this makes a feeling of you looking at events from aside like a viewer of a movie. This little masterpiece will absolutely not make you regret spending time playing this game. Great overall experinece.  Прекрасный пример хорошей игры. Очень личная, трогательная история о дружбе и верности, местами очень теплая и нежная, но и не скрывающая и самых темных сторон человеческой души. Эта история не тронет лишь самых черствых людей. Прекрасный подбор музыки, которая замечательно поддерживает и передает атмосферу всего происходящего в игре. Стилизованная графика, местами выдающая завораживающие картины, также привносит в игру особое восприятие событий. Геймплей не требует никакого напряжения от игрока, за счет чего создается созидательный эффект, будто бы наблюдаешь за всем со стороны как в кино. Это маленький шедевр, проведя время за которым, вы явно не пожалеете.

A moving coming-of-age story about an 18 year old photography student who discovers that she has the ability to rewind time – set in a fictional town in the American state of Oregon – inspired by stuff like Twin Peaks. It has plenty of tonal variety, jumping from being a teen drama to a crime thriller, whilst dealing with all kinds of everyday social issues that most games rarely dare to tackle. Above all, it’s a tale of true friendship. Life is Strange stars a wonderful cast of realistic characters (aided by excellent voice acting), who at first may seem like archetypes yet are gradually developed over the course of each episode to become quite human. Some of the people you will meet are at first almost objectively abhorrent, but many of them turn into actually likeable personas by the end of this graphic adventure, showing that a coin always has two sides.  It is difficult for aspects of Maxine’s journey to not resonate with the player’s life experiences in at least some ways; anyone who was (or still is) a teenager between the 1990s and 2010s will likely relate to much of what is presented here. Visually, Life is Strange is absolutely beautiful – although it does not try to be photorealistic, it is nevertheless detailed and genuine. The only problem here is the subpar lip-syncing along with the facial animations in general, which must be this game’s largest flaw (other than rare glitches and occasional frame rate drops)… but that doesn’t stop it from being an emotional voyage that has brought many gamers to tears. It is definitely helped by the great sound design, thanks to an original composed score as well as clever use of licensed music.  Now that the first episode of Life is Strange has been made free, you can try it to see whether it is something you will enjoy. However, please do not judge the whole product based only on its first fifth as the game becomes much more complex later on with numerous plot twists and extensive character development. If you liked The Walking Dead, or The Last of Us and its Left Behind DLC, chances are that you will love LiS just as much. Plus it actually has more content and is still cheaper than Telltale’s recent offerings – most people seem to finish it in about 15 hours, but if you play at a leisurely pace to explore environments, see different options and really take in the ambience of all those introspective moments then you will easily squeeze a lot more time out of it (my first playthrough took me 22 hours).  Sure, it's not perfect and it's not a game for everyone. But if it clicks with you, then it will probably hit you quite hard. And like I said earlier, it's worth giving it a go. Many people who at the start thought they did not belong to the demographic this game supposedly aims at ended up loving it.

Life is Strange is a point & click adventure game that offers a great experience as it allows you to follow a very beautiful and interesting story and connect with the characters inside it. It's is exactly the type of adventure game that is so story-driven that almost feels like you are put inside a movie and able to change the course of events with your choices. Choices matter. A lot. And with them it allows the player to shape his/her own very special turn of events and actions all related around a very specific core background that follows a chain reaction of actions and consequences through time and space.  You play as Max, an art college teenager that dreams to become a famous photographer and who gets in a college located in a town where she spent her childhood accompanied by Chloe, who used to be her best friend.  Max is a photography geek, a very low profile character and a shy person while Chloe having to go through different circumstances of life has turned out to be a dropout punk chick who gets often into trouble and hides a very sweet core beneath her tough behavior.  The story starts the moment you, playing as Max, find out that you have the special power to rewind time for a few seconds or minutes, allowing you to actually be able to undo and redo actions, choices and dialogues, giving you the feeling of control over reality. A feeling that turns out to be less and less strong as laws of chaos theory and relativity begin to take over leading you to a climax of events and choices that will even test your consensus and the way you understand the world you have emerged in.  The game, depending the way you play it - and how your own character and ethics are as a person, can turn out to be a unique symbolic corner-stone of what friendship is about and offers you one of the most basic morals that a human brain must cope with in life, that for every action in life, there's always a reaction.  Technical-wise the game has simplified graphics, probably playable by most hardware setups, it is amazingly designed and voice acted. There's a lot of color, attention to cinematic-like environmental settings and the direction is very well done. And i'm talking about actual direction tricks being used, like camera views well combined with background actions, dialogue combinations, and some times well balanced views.  In addition, during your run you will be accompanied by some very nicely selected music tracks (the OST are indeed amazing).  10/10 Recommended. Most defo. One of the best of its genre.

Life is Strange  is an exquisitely human game, and that quality is reflected in the warmth of its fan community here. They are welcoming of newcomers, eager to discuss the game's imponderables, and respectful of opinions. Stop by; you'll be happy you did.

Okay, so, I am a big fan of telltale's interactive story 'games', and went into this with many past story game experiences under my belt. I was expecting something good, based on steam's reviews and my past experience with such games, and boy was I in for a surprise.   I was expecting something good, but what I got was something phenomenal. Sure, the mouth flaps didn't sync perfectly with the voice acting, but damn it I don't care! Right away I was interested in our main heroine and her journey into becoming a photographer, I expected a slice of life take on entering adulthood and going your own way, but I was immediately surprised by a twist I wasn't expecting, having gone into the game relatively cold of knowledge about it's story. The characters are all believable, and through 'natural' voice acting from some lesser known actors, the characters get a new layer of realism and allow you to identify with, and relate to them a little more easily.   The only game I can equate this to from any past experience I've had is probably 'Gone Home', it's a very personal quest that Max is on, trying to find herself, and then she gets mixed up in a totally bizarro situation, but the whole thing is sort of grounded in this believable, real world.  I sat down, dimmed the lights, put on my headphones, and lost myself in the awesomeness of this game's atmosphere and character. I beat the first 'episode' in about a 3 hour session of play, and that's looking at everything, talking to everyone (sometimes a few times for different results) and generally getting the most out of the chapter, and at roughly 3 hours per episode, this series is looking to be a solid 15 hour epic! And for $5.50 for the first chapter, I'd say it's worth every cent.   I know these thoughts I'm having are sort of all over the place, it's because I'm having a hard time properly expressing just how much I enjoyed the first Episode of this series, and i am eagerly awaiting the next... and next and next installments.   I went into this game expecting a good time, and I came out being a little sad that I had already finished the first part and have to wait so long for the next. This wasn't just a game, it was an experience, I thought about my moments with the first episode for about 2 days after I finished, and am still mulling over the events, the atmosphere, the character, and of course the wonderful soundtrack of in game songs and themes.   So, in conclusion, I rambled a lot, but everything about my time with Life is Strange is great, I enjoyed every second of it, and I hope that everyone else does too. Get this game, if not then at LEAST get the first episode to wet your feet, and see if you like it enough to take the (super affordable) 20 dollar plunge.  YES YES YES, get it.  EDIT: I have since of course finished the entirety of the game, and my thoughts have not wavered. The game gets incredibly more interesting and even quite dark, the feels overwhelm and you find yourself feeling sad alongside these characters you've come to see almost as friends of your own.   Life is Strange is the best game I've ever played, not because it's the most technically impressive, or has the best story, or has the best world... But because when I was playing; it was able to immerse me into this real world, it made me feel like I was apart of the story and interacting with these characters. I love this game, it's my favorite, and I got a tattoo, lest I never forget the impact this game has had on me.

This is seriously one of the best games I've played in a long time. I was just playing the Longest Journey and totally digging it. I heard this game was coming out and the teaser seemed really awesome. Now that I am playing it, I must say the attention to detail is off the charts. I'd recommend that you pay attention to your decisions because I didn't realize how quickly my decisions would affect the course of the story. The power to rewind time threw me in the beginning changing trivial things and altering the decisions I had made with conversations. But all in all that is what makes this game amazing. Even the smallest decision you make seems to alter the future in someway. It is truly a masterpiece in game design, art design and how a simple mechanic can make a choose your own adventure (already great in it's own right) into something truly amazing. You should buy it immediately.

Episode One: Chrysalis blew me away. Beautiful! Beautiful graphics, Beautiful soundtrack... Just sersiously effin beautiful!  Life is Strange relies on a choice and consequence narrative in which you take on the role of high school student Max Caulfield who has just discovered her ability to rewind time. The game focuses on Max's school life but also sheds a light on her relationships and the mysterious disappearance of a local girl.  As Max, you navigate school life through a linear path, interacting with classmates, teachers and friends through choice-driven conversation. However, these decisions aren't set in stone; once a conversation is finished, you are able to 'rewind' time. You can relive a scenario as often as you like choosing which path to take and therefore which consequence may follow that.  Looking forward to the next episodes!!

This is only a review for episode 1 and it's a good start. If you enjoy Telltale's adventure games, you'll probably feel at home with Dontnod's foray into the genre. One of the most striking things I came to realize was how much better these modern adventure games can feel when they're built with solid technical design. I felt so much more absorbed into the story without all of the stuttering, texture dropouts, and crashes that seem to be so consistent in Telltale games. This game looks and runs like a dream, with beautiful, confident, and unique visual design.  In spite of some cringeworthy dialogue here and there (they lean a little heavy on teenage lingo that's occasionally dated and a little out of place) I found myself connecting and getting invested in the characters and their drives very nicely. The time rewinding mechanic was a fun way to play around with the short term impacts of your actions that I hope will be expanded upon in later episodes. When I finished this episode, I had found myself so enamored with the experience, I played it through one more time to get the achievements and see the consequences of actions I didn't take the first time around.  I'm finding myself slowly becoming a Dontnod groupie after thoroughly enjoying Remember Me and now the first episode of Life is Strange. Their games aren't perfect, but the unique female driven angles they take and solid technical execution are really something I value. I whole heartedly recommend this.

One of the best games I've ever played. Or is it more an interactive story? Hell who the hell cares, this is just a must have.  The story is mature, it can clearly fight big names in sci-fi and storytelling. Names like Ray Bradbury (who also inspired the authors), movies like The Butterfly Effect, and anime like Higurashi nu naku koro ni. It almost feels like you are living a story in this adventure.  As for execution, the graphics perfectly fit the game, the authors didn't aim for triple-A photorealistic graphics, but a stylized one. And hell, that makes this story even better. Gameplay, this is how adventures in 21st century should look like. It is the way 3D adventures should go and tell stories.  I see that these authors did what I'm aiming for (and what I'd like to create one day). They didn't just create another game, they told a story - a masterpiece.

Life is Strange is an episodic story-based game (similar to popular Telltale titles) revolving around Max, a photography Senior who soon discovers that she has the ability to rewind time, allowing her to change how events played out and give herself an edge over her classmates. Little does she realize, changing the way events play out can have considerable after-effects.  The game quickly drops you into Max's world of school life, one that is riddled with mysteries that keep you asking questions and wanting to learn more about the events taking place around you. There is no denying that after the first episode of Life is Strange, DONTNOD know what they are doing. Life is Strange easily rivals popular Telltale titles set in the same Episodic Story-based fashion.  The voice acting is superb and really makes you feel like Max's classmates are real people with real problems and helps draw you into Max's world which is filled to the brim with tidbits of information that you can learn just by exploring, providing tons of interesting dialogue that expands your view of life in Arcadia Bay.  The art-style used in the game is simply perfect and fits in a way that, once drawn in, makes you forget that Max's world is one of fiction.  Episode 1 offers around one and a half hours of gameplay if you play the story straight through without much exploration which is to be expected for the first episode of an episodic series.  I very much look forward to Episode 2.

After playing this game... I'm feelin like ♥♥♥♥! It was hella ride. Jeez... I couldn't stop play it... Even though I don't see any ♥♥♥♥ bcs my tears were just all over my face. THIS GAME! THIS GAME JUST DESTROY MY FEELINGS!!!!  15/10 would play again until they end like Kate from this

Too be honest, I didnt know what I was getting myself into when I played this game for the first time. I was bored out of my mind so I decided to purchase Life Is Strange because my friend had suggested it to me. I wanted something to cure my bordem but what I got was so much more than that and I'm grateful.  I don't consider myself an emotional type of guy and have never felt really 'torn up' over how a video game or movie ended, but that was changed at 7:00 AM when I stayed up all night and morning to reach the end of this fantasic experience. This game tore me open like a lion devouring it's prey and as the end credits rolled, tears ran down my face. The pure emotion I had over this game was insane and I never wanted it to stop.   As somebody who instantly fell in love with Chloe,   watching her die so much messed with me more than I anticipated   and I'm not sure if I should be angry at the developers or thanking them for their genius and awesome work at making me so connected to her. I relate to her problems in more ways than one, so learning more about her character turned her from 'the cool chick with the cool hair' into 'the person I must protect no matter what'. During my playthrough I chose the romatic path between Max and Chloe which only made the ending 100x harder to do, but I felt the connection between them.   Now about the problem I had with the ending.  It was easy to see that the developers wanted you to sacrafice Chloe and get the more fufilling, emotional ending. Thats why they deliberately made the save Chloe ending as bland and unfufilling as possible which I don't agree with at all. If you give players a choice, make them feel like it actually matters. Fanfiction can only do so much.   Now about how I felt with the events leading up to it and the choice I made.    I chose to save Chloe. If it's not obvious yet, I'm a huge Chloe fanboy. But that didn't really influnce my decision as much as you'd think. What did influence it was the bond that developed throughout the entire game between Chloe and Max. When I made the final choice the first thing I thought about was every intimate moment, every bonding session, every time they spilt their guts out to each other, and every time Max defied reality to save the person closest to her.    I wasn't going to let everything that was done go to waste. And everytime I ask myself why I made this choice I reply to myself with, 'love is the why.'  I would go into 1000x more detail but this is crushing me so I'm going to wrap it up. Get this game at all ♥♥♥♥ing costs. 10/10 experience, 10/10 characters, 10/10 story, and 10/10 everything else.   ENJOY THE HEARTACHE I KNOW IM NOT
simply wonderful. I you like a story-laden game.. this is it.

One of the most memorable experiences I've ever had playing a videogame. Going into this having absolutely no idea what to expect, I ended up loving every minute. The soundtrack is unforgettable and beautiful, and extremely pleasant to listen to whilst working. The emphasis on nostalgia and longing for childhood is particularly relatable for almost anyone I can imagine, and is portrayed extremely well, which is an extremely good achievement given it’s such a unique and personal feeling. This game takes a lot of aspects from the Butterfly Effect (great film, watch it if you haven’t) and almost feels like a tasteful video game version of the film. The art direction is beautiful with fantastic colours and lighting which really adds a sense of depth and feeling whilst playing the game, the visual tone works harmoniously with the soundtrack and story at all points. If you like story driven Telltale type games; do yourself a favour and play this. Play it with a friend/partner, you owe it to yourself.

Everyone should play this game. Honestly, what you are going to get out of this game depends on what you've been through in life. I lost my mom when I was 16 and was able to relate to quite a bit of the ♥♥♥♥ going on. You may relate more to other parts of the story.   In this game, your choices do matter. The consequences probably will crush you, and if you paid attention to the point of the game at all, the ending should neither be surprising nor a reason to dislike the game. Yes, it comes down to just one choice, but the two options you are given will be heavily weighted based on how you played the game. Unfortunately, the developers clearly wanted everyone to choose the one ending, so the other one does not do a good job of showing you the consequences of your choice. However, the developers do an amazing job when it comes to tackling the unpredictability of life. Everyone thinks they can change things, and everyone thinks they are the hero of their own story, but sometimes things are out of our control and the choices we make, regardless of good intentions, end up doing more harm than good.   So play this game. When it's all over, you'll be glad you did.

Okay. This is one of the best stories I have ever experienced in my entire life. Just for the record - I love telltale games, but this - I could basically feel the impact of the choices that I had made - and all those consequences many episodes later. And in my opinion, this is really level up in choice-based gaming. Some people get bored during first two episodes - well guess what - the game will emotionally break you in the next ones.  11/10 One of the best games I have ever played and it totally got me. And everytime I hear 'Obstacles' or even just see the picture of Chloe and Maxine, I can feel heart-breaking thoughts in my head.

This game hurt to play. There have been games that surprised me in some ways. Sometimes I laugh a little or feel  something ... But at one point in Life Is Strange™ I cried and had to put down the game for a few days. No other game has made me feel such sadness to any comparable degree.  I initially decided to purchase this because it is a narrative-centric game that is well received. I knew little about it beforehand and was thus ambivalent when starting the game for the first time. It opened in a scene with beautiful music and immediately made me feel like I was in for a treat.  The game grabbed me and never let go.

Quirky characters, beautiful art style, great sound track, and satisfying descision making that is complimented nicely with the time manipulation mechanic. Some of the setpieces felt incredibly tense as you repeatedly rewind time to resolve the problem at hand, and scenes where the game strips you of your ability and leave you to your own devices are especially satisfying when resolved. The story feels both large in scope yet incredibly intimate, with characters you care about and relate to.  I'm eagerly awaiting episode 3 to come, I have no idea where the story will go, but the ride is well designed and oozes an indie movie style charm. This is one of the first games since Mass Effect that I've genuinely cared about the well being of the characters. The scenes where they are in danger are stressful as they should be, and each descision leaves you with a lingering doubt whether you made the best choice despite being able to rewind and see out the other options.  I can't recommend this game highly enough, brilliant work.
Starts off slow but only gets better and better with each episode. Solid scenario, great soundtrack and characters. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes episodic, story driven games.

An absolutely beautiful game.  Many people in the 'Negative' reviews pass it off as 'cliche', when really it's nostalgic. It perfectly sums up the teenage years when everyone hung around in 'groups' that tried to be 'cooler' than one another. Then it introduces the entire aspect of the narrative, that you can reverse time to stop things from happening that you don't like, or to retry something to see what the alternative outcome is.  It's more than just 'typical highschool drama' as another commenter mentioned, it's about what you'd sacrifice for your friends, even if it meant unravelling the very fabric of time.  Truly, an amazing game, gets you thinking whilst having a factor of nostalgia ever so present in the background.

The game is incredible, at first,i thought this would be one of those generic visual novel dramas or something, that is until a friend played it and i saw it myself,your actions affect details throughout the story and everything has at the very least some background lines behind it or even sometimes a remark from the character talking to herself as you examine things around,time travel here is more easily described as a rewind system,made a mistake a few seconds ago?,no prbloem,hold down the button and youll see it go back to how it was,enabling you to make a better choice meanwhile still having that bit of info or details you learned through the mistake,carefull tho,you cant exacly time travel to any point through your whole progress,so its better used as a trial and error kind of thing within a few moments of gameplay,dlc might look a little blegh for those who dont like them,but its actually very good,dlc's are chapter to progress through the story and with each one the story essentialy intensifies in secrets and interesting plot points,tho theres a couple of loopholes i cant quite understand regarding her powers(mostly because i like time travel movies/games/anime and just went ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when i found she can time travel without really touching some topics like how Stein's Gate has multiple timelines,or how she can even go that far back later on without any explanation whatsoever),it doesnt realy matter,the point isnt about her powers and all,the point of the game is to show the struggles of a teen and how she deals with it through special circumstances,often in the game presenting characters with real teenage struggles and life problems,i highly reccomend at the very least giving it a try,even if youre not a fan of games that dont need a gun to work,i promise this game wont dissapoint.

The graphics are okayish (I dont like the style too much, but I understand it's more fitting than any high-res modern graphics would be). Life is Strange flawlessly brings together mystery, nostalgia, drama, and most of all heart. There are few games that can pull on your heartstrings the way that this game is able. The simple mechanic of rewinding time allowed the player to truly explore each character and each interaction. While you could quickly see what the immediate outcome would be, each choice impacted a later point in the game in both subtle and dramatic ways. By the end of the game, you may even find yourself making less 'game-y', 'min-max' decisions in favor of personal choice which makes it jump leaps and bounds ahead of most choice driven competition.  I whole-heartedly reccomend this game to anyone and everyone. This isn't just a gamer's game, or a casual game. This is a game for everyone that takes a mechanic and explores it to its fullest.

An awesome experience. This is what i want the evolution of adventure games to look like. Hell, finally some studios can make interesting games without mass murder and destruction, and do an actual mature, well made, polished, interesting storyline. Kudos on Square Enix who took the risk to produce such an awesome new franchise.   I got episode one during the summer sale. No way i'm waiting for the next sale on this great game. Picked up the complete season after i finished episode one, who lasted me 2 hours. Even more awesome is the fact that the choices you make actually affects future events and stuff happens differently later. Also, when you finish the episode game tells you what other players worldwide did in such and such situation. Pure awesome.   Wholeheartedly recomended.

The only problem I had with the game is that you're choices never really had an impact on the ending. Whatever you do, you'll be given 2 choices and they are available to you regardless of what you choices you've made before. I guess to sum it up, it lacked the variety of endings I could see this game could've made. I wanted to be able to get all the endings and it took me roughly 5 minutes after finishing it once to get the 2nd end. I wished there were things like the true end, good end, bad end, etc. It had so much potential and it built the characters and the story. You could see it go in different directions only to end up in a very limited setting, and those 2 choices you ended up with aren't really all that great imho.  The impact of your choices were referenced albeit only as a minor appearance in the game. It opened you to some choices sure, but those choices really had no prominent role aside from a feeling of kinda like a cool easter egg.  Chapters 1 through 4 were great I got absorbed in the story. The way they handled the reveals, plot twists, and how they made the characters grow on you is excellent. The ending however could've been WAY better. 9/10

Literally only played this game because I got it free in a bundle at the start of this year, and as a guy in his 20s I didn't think it would interest me in the slightest. I only decided to try it one night when I was super bored and waiting for some other game to download.  This is literally one of if not my favourite game(s) of all time.  Why?  Mostly because it has this way that it genuinely moves you with its story and its characters. I had no idea why but I found myself relating to Max and Chloe, the teen girls at the centre of the game's narrative. I genuinely cared about what happened to them and the people of Arcadia Bay.  Personally I can't fault this game. At all.  I only wish I can experience it again for the first time... Max, if you're reading this, do your thing girl.

At first I came into this game having only seen a peek at episode 1 and I thought to myself 'Just some more teenage drama bs.'. But then I actually decided to give it a shot, and all i have to say is... wow. It's hard to summarize how good this game is in words but I'll try. When I started playing it and it was feeding into the teen drama crap in the classroom, I felt like my original thought of the game was correct. But then seeing Chloe get shot and now all of the sudden I'm back at class, I was shocked, honestly shocked to the point of I sat there for a minute trying to gather myself. When I finally started going again I realised that I could sue my powers to gain the edge in conversations, which added a whole new level of depth into the game for me. So I went through the whole of episode one, captivated by this new world that was before me.   Buying the season pass was the easiest buy I have ever made and I recommend whoever is reading this do the same as me. Watching how the decisions I made in episode one pan out and having to sit back and watch as the reality before me shatters due to my actions. This game truly captured the feeling fo regret, a feeling that seems almost impossible with time travel. This game is teaching a lesson on this, no matter what you do, no matter who you are, and no matter how many times you try, you will always regret something whether it's big or small. I remember a moment where I was sitting in my chair shaking, I kept rewinding begging for a better way for something to end but every option ended with someone getting hurt in one way or another.  DONTNOD Entertainment, thank you for giving us something that if games were ever defined as art, this would be solid proof of that. You've made me happy, sad, cheerful, and made me cry. I end my review by saying this, Life is Strange deserves a place in gaming history, and I hope this will be used as a model that people will follow when they make their own games. I give this game a 10 out of 10, I honestly cannot fathom anyone giving it anything lower than that, this is art, this is beautiful, this is a masterpiece.
Wow My most Favorite game for 2015 this game deserves like the best game i the world crown!! I totally reccomend this game and i will never stop playing it 10/10

I've never written a review for a game before now. I finally decided to do it for Life Is Strange because I can't stop thinking about it. This game moved me so much, with its intense level of emotion, all of its personable and unforgettable characters, and its drive to shock and entertain. Life Is Strange gives an excellent, intricate look at the effect your choices can have on your life and the world around you. If anything, this game is interesting and immersive, and probably worth your time.

The whole making the first episode free thing is evil. You'll immediately buy the rest of the game after playing the first episode. It's like they laid one free fun-size Butterfinger on the ground for you to enjoy, and then stashed a whole pile of Butterfingers in the middle of a nearby field of bear traps. 'Damn, that Butterfinger was good. Heyyy, more Butterfingers!'  I know I sound stupid but Life is Strange is honestly art and is the only game I've played that has ever made me cry. Seriously, give this game a try.

This is one of the most intensely absorbing games I've ever played. It's a strange, complicated, dreamy alternate reality where every choice matters.  As a bonus, if I have lucid dreams I will often have a camera with me to take photos.   10/10

Great, complex, charismatic characters? Check. Well thought, dramatic, cliff hanging plot? Check. AWESOME soundtrack? Check. Good, optimized graphics? Check. Nice controls? Double check!  I give it 12/10! It is totally worth the money, even at full price.  Sometimes, Life is Strange made me laugh. It also brought me to tears. Playing this immersive game truly affected my emotional state, as the tough choices I had to make as Max were to me all a kind of small metaphores to everything I've been dealing with in real life -- I am the same age as the main character of the game and, hence, found it very easy to relate to her. It's a game that probably will make you rethink your whole life after you finish every chapter.

While it's incredibly disappointing that the final episode does not care about your decisions throughout the game in factoring the ending, it was still incredibly fun and interesting to play through this five part series. If you can manage to dismiss some of the more cringe inducing dialogue Chloe utters, you'll find a creative and clever Telltale-like narrative that'll captivate you, much like it captivated me.

Now this is a game I highly recommend. The Visuals it’s a stellar but it’s the story that's gripping and captivating. You play the role of an 18 year old portage named Max. She wakes up from a horrible dream that soon she realizes is an omen and discovers she had the ability to reverse time. Life is Strange....  Life is Strange is a Sorybased game that puts the player in the town of Arcadia Bay in the state of Oregon. You play as the 18 Yrs. old Maxine Caulfield. I have never written a review before today. That being said, I feel that after playing episode one, I have an obligation to add to the overwhelming number of astounding feedback which this game has already accumulated. The reason for these amazing reviews is simply because this is a true masterpiece. In all my hours of playing story given, decision making games, I have never experienced anything close to what this game is able to accomplish. I admire a game that can get me to feel for the characters; I praise a game that takes that one step further, going beyond what any other story can do, making the player truly have experiences. Through smooth, well crafted gameplay and mechanics, I was transformed into the character of Max (also notable considering I am male). I was able to feel like the story was built for me, which is a truly amazing feeling. If you take nothing else away from this review, know that it has life. It's a game with feeling and emotion, and one which will really make you think about each and every action you take. It's up to you to decide whether or not you purchase this game, but remember, this choice has consequences.

This game heavily relies on atmosphere and character colour/drama, as such you will be treated to many long unskipable cut-scenes with accompanied (mostly acoustic guitar) music. These happen very frequent and give the game a strong film/TV feel. Due to this, your enjoyment of the game will be dictated by your enjoyment of the story elements and interest in the characters. Play episode 1 for free to judge if they match your taste.  My thoughts? Yeah, it's a fairly good P&C game. The rewind mechanic mostly functions as a puzzle solving tool, but one can also use it to change any choice made in-game, thus enabling you to experience all the immediate resulting variations of your choices without requiring multiple playthroughs; but rewind does not show long-term results (if any exist).  The puzzles are very easy and mostly serve as in-game 'speed bumps' to slow progress; in fact many puzzle solutions only become available once you hit a mandatory fail-state, forcing you to use your rewind mechanic. The game designed the choice system well and your decisions have a varying level of impact on the NPC interactions, however don't expect an ability to make story driven choices as there is really only one track of story to follow. Nevertheless the dialog options do add colour to the tale.

Quirky characters, beautiful art style, great sound track, and satisfying descision making that is complimented nicely with the time manipulation mechanic. Some of the setpieces felt incredibly tense as you repeatedly rewind time to resolve the problem at hand, and scenes where the game strips you of your ability and leave you to your own devices are especially satisfying when resolved. The story feels both large in scope yet incredibly intimate, with characters you care about and relate to.  I'm eagerly awaiting episode 3 to come, I have no idea where the story will go, but the ride is well designed and oozes an indie movie style charm. This is one of the first games since Mass Effect that I've genuinely cared about the well being of the characters. The scenes where they are in danger are stressful as they should be, and each descision leaves you with a lingering doubt whether you made the best choice despite being able to rewind and see out the other options.  I can't recommend this game highly enough, brilliant work.

Life is Strange Review 26.10.2015  THIS REVIEW WONT CONTAIN ANY SPOILERS  I write this review after I've played all 5 episodes in about a week. So what is 'Life is Strange'?  First of all: THIS GAME WONT BE WHAT YOU EXPECT IT TO BE. Until now I've only played Telltales story driven games and almost everytime I was fascinated by the storytelling. But what Dontnod did here is simply amazing.  It first of starts like a story driven by a typical highschool drama. You play Max Caulfield, a teenager that just turned 18 years old and moved from Seattle back to her old hometown, Arcadia Bay.  She attends to some kind of elite highschool, The Blackwell Academy, and loves photography. Her teacher is the famous photographer and artist Mark Jefferson. Max's classmates are also the typical ones. You will find ♥♥♥♥♥es,bullies and nerds.  These different classmates will also have a huge impact on the story and Max's journey.   Can you befriend them or will they hate you?  In the first 5 minutes of the game you will discover which powers Max has got. She can rewind time! This mechanic will be often used throughout the game to reserve decisions or add information to a conversation that you just gathered later.  With those powers she manages to save a girl in the girls bathroom.  After this events the story starts and gets more tense every minute.  But what she didn't know: The girl she just saved was her best friend from her childhood , Chloe Price. Together they try to solve the mistery about the disappearance of Rachel Amber.  Also weather is changing.... can Max find out what causes these changes?  She has to put her powers to good use throughout the whole storyline. Is it worth changing time? What will happen if you do? You will have to play it yourself. :)  Another great aspect are the great written characters. They feel like real human beings and you will be attached to them as soon as you meet them. The game also sends out important messages about life out to the players. It will teach alot of things and is a really valuable experience. In some moments it will shock you, but also open your eyes.  Another reason to buy this game is the beautiful soundtrack. There are so many well chosen songs in this game, it's amazing! I found so many artist through this game and its music. It always manages to touch you and trigger some heavy emotions! :)  Every episode gets better and ends with a boom. Dontnod really overdid themselfes here. It's their second game and they delivered a top-notch story with beautiful characters. I promise. After the end there will be an emptiness inside of you and you will think about this game a long time. These characters grow to you like real friends. You simply are part of their story. Have fun guys!  Its my Game of the Year and a 10/10

After playing Firewatch I didn't have much hope of finding another story rich game that tugged at my heart strings but holy god did this one deliver. Dat soundtrack tho. Please make a season 2 I keep looking for more games like this.

Acting is pretty great and animation is well done. Overall, it is one of the better choose-your-own-adventure games.

I honestly have never had a game lift my spirit up as much as 'life is strange' did. I was an emotional wreck after every harsh thing that happened. Life is Strange is a pure masterpiece. The characters leave you thinking so much about why they are who they are. There are some open ended questions about them, why they are the way they are, if they love who you think they love - and yet they are so well developed it is clear who they are and why. You get to decide a small bit about why they act how they act based on the story line and it does not take away from who they are.  Let's face it, the scenery and world are outstanding. A super emersive environment that is gorgeous, full of life and detail and helps complete the story well.  This game plays like your very own quirky indie flick, where you get to decide how it plays out. The decision making is great because you can change up how the game plays, but not in such a way that it changes the entire integrity of the story.  The story itself is intriguing and interesting enough to keep you wrapped up from the beginning, and it keeps you wrapped throughout although there are some very interesting twists and turns you'll never see coming.  There are some particulars that will leave you speechless, some moments that will take your breath away, episodes that will leave you on the edge of your seat, and some that will wrap you up in feels the whole time.  I can only say positive things aout this game without trying really hard to find something ridiculous and knit picky wrong with it. It is as close to perfect as this genre of game can get, and it left me utterly sad that it had to end.  Almost better than any of the greatest books I have read, and has an emotional impact on you as you play from episode one through five.  I laughed a bit, I was scared, I was shocked, concerned and even a bit teary eyed at times. If you only play one game this year, or forever - this one will touch you for a long, long time.  10/10 - Would get feels again. Over and over and over again.  Pure Genious.  Thank You

One of the best imersive games I've ever played. Love it, and fell in love with the characters. I just wish episode four and five could have been better. The ending Is okay, it was kinda of okay for me, but did have shades of Mass Effect Three. I do wish more effort was spent on the last episode (longer, and more story driving, more content), really if Dontnot had done that they would have a game which would be impossible to beat for a long time. But of course, these comments don't distract from the fact, that this game is a 'must not be missed at all costs' experience.

This game made me cry, twice!  The game is about Max Caulfield grew up in Arcadia Bay but moved to Seatle 5 years ago, just after her best friends (Chloe) dad died in a car accident. Now she's going back to Arcadia Bay to attend to Blackwell Academy. The game starts with Max discovering her gift/power: being able to go back in time. After 5 years of not seeing or writing to Chloe they meet up again. She has turn Punk as a way to express her pain: Her father died, Max left her and Rachel disappeared ... Rachel was Chloe's new best friend after Max moved away. The story is centered around Chloe and trying to find out what happened to Rachel.  Dontnod Entertainment did an absolute great job of every part of the game: - the way time travel was used in a narrative game - choice of music - the story - story telling and directing - rewarding players that try to discover everything - artstyle and graphics

What key do I press to lay down and cry in the fetal position? This game ♥♥♥♥ed me up big time.  Pros:   + Amazing art style, looks like a watercolor painting. + Interesting characters. + Your decisions will actually impact the game. TellTale needs to take some notes. + Intriguing story with plot twists around every corner. + At least 5 or so big decisions per episode. + Delves deep into your feelings to make you feel really bad when you mess up. + Collectibles and different decisions add some replayability. + Great voice acting. + The ending is unforgettable. + The soundtrack is unique and fits the game perfectly. + Episode 5 will have you scratching your head saying 'What the ♥♥♥♥ is going on?'.  Cons:  - The characters look a little lifeless sometimes and aren't very good at showing emotion. - Dialogue can be plain cringeworthy at times. The game uses memes from 2011 at certain parts and just ends up embarassing itself. - 'Hella'. - Lip syncing is just plain bad.  Verdict:   Life Is Strange is a game worth buying if you're looking for a phenomenal story. At certain times in the game, it tends to just be a white girl simulator, but it's a good white girl simulator. Episode 1 doesn't do a very good job of getting the player intrigued, but after Episode 2 there's no going back. This game will stick with you long after you've finished it. The Game Earns: 8.4 / 10

Easily the best 2015 game I've played. The storytelling is so great and unlike many Telltales (don't get me wrong: stories are cool in them) your actual choices do matter - or at least, seem to - due to the rewind time-theme of the game. The game also addressed some of the so-called social taboos on bullying, suicide, and the themes of episode 5 which I would spoil the entire game with should I put them here. I finished my first play through of this game a few days ago and I can't get it out of my heart. While I sit here typing this, I am listening to the bittersweet guitar tune from the game...and I am quite sad. Yes, I feel like an idiot for admitting that, but what you need to know here is that this is an INCREDIBLE game. And to call it 'a game' is quite nearly an insult to the effort of the developers.  This is an experience. A test. A journey.  'Life Is Strange' is fun, entertaining, interesting...but it is also uncommonly compelling, intriguing, and heart-felt. It is a game that makes you think as it reaches into your mind, tests your scruples and tugs at your heart srtings. If you are like me, you will in equal parts, become Max, wish you were Max, thank God that you are NOT Max...and feel deeply for her. You will want to coach her, cajole her, motivate her. She will then amaze you, bewilder you, and twist at your emotions. Then you will realize that, in a very big way, you are Max...and Max is you.  'Life Is Strange' is an amazingly well put together tale that unfolds based on decisions you make while given the opportunity try different approaches in reaching these decisions. Once you become immersed in the game, you find yourself using Max's power to test different responses in difficult situations, but ultimately you must make a choice, take a stance...and then live with it. And the effect these choice can and do have...can be staggering.   If you COULD change the past, present or future...would you? Knowing Not knowing if or how unanticipated ripples could dramatically affect you, or someone close to you.   Would you?  Bottom line, I consider this to be one of the best, most amazing gaming experiences of my life. The visuals are incredible, the look and feel is so realistic, the music choices and stying is spot on, and the voice acting is absolutely brilliant.  I am grateful to the developers for taking the time to create a smart, thoughtful and brilliantly executed piece of entertainment. When they come out with their next creation, I wll be there.  Life Is Strange.  Yeah, it's 'just a game'. But I found it to be sweet, touching, highly entertaining and in the end...heart breaking.   Stupid game.  I hope you play, take good care of Max, and come back and tell me what you think.

This game is like being in an immersive interactive movie and it hits you in the feels a lot.. It definetly is catered to the current generation of coming to age kids, but you can still relate and fall in love with the story and characters even if you're older. The story is wonderfully told, and the soundtrack compliments the atmosphere and tone of everything perfectly. I felt like I was playing a chick flick movie or Tumblr: The Movie at times, but once you look past some of the stereotypes and hipster stuff it really is a very enjoyable experience..  I've always been a fan of movies with time paradox like Back to the Future, The Butterfly Effect, Project Almanac and such.. The themes are similar, and the consequence of having the power to alter time will have an impact big or small on the future. I had a heavy Butterfly Effect vibe throughout the majority of the game, due to the dynamic of the story being told and the drama that unfolds being very similar.   The fact you can't just go back and load a new save makes the decision making process much better, you have to go with your gut on what you think Max would do.. That's another thing, you really find yourself thinking like Max would think, not so much what you personally would think and that really added to the immersiveness of the game for me.  While I felt the game could of been a bit longer and Episode 5 could of been a bit less rushed, the character development and experience really gives that a pass.. It's been a long time since I've been able to care for minor characters in a game until playing this. Every decision you make you wonder what it will change as the story goes on, and leaves you wondering if it was the right choice.   My only real gripe is even though your decision making does impact the story, there are actually only two endings and your decisions made throughout the game don't really impact those endings at all. I do wish there were numerous endings, or at least 3-4 tops just to give some variety based on your choices.. SPOILERS BELOW  You know, I want to start off by saying I never review games. I ususally take time to read them and my purchase is heavily influenced by reviews, but I suppose I just couldn't have been bothered, this game is different. I read some reviews telling how phenomenal the character depth was and how heart wrenching the story was, but I've always found my self emotionally secure so I did not think for a moment this game would ever force me to tears, like I said, this game is different.  I honestly have to commend Dontnod for this work of art, because never in my life have I been so drawn in to a game or have I seemingly felt the same emotions the characters were going through. One thing I have always loved about games and books, is when playing or reading one actually makes you stop and think, and you gain a different perspective on things in life. I feel like there are many people who would like (or claim they would) the ability to go back in time and right some wrongs or do things differently, myself included, but after playing this game and the consequences you see for the actions you chose, it makes me honest to god joyful I don't have such a burden weighing down on me. The story in this game is more like an experience than just a plot, in my opinion, this is one of the best games I have played in a long time, Only problems I had, I'd like the Lip-syncing to be little better, and I would've liked it if the smaller, seemingly inconsequential things actually had a bigger impact, i.e. letting your plant live/die, helping Alyssa not get hit by things, saving the bird in Joyce's home, etc. One thing I noticed many people complain about was the final epsiode where (SPOILER) with the final choice, you learn that every decision up to this point was relatively meaningless, there are only two endings, sacrifice chloe and save arcadia bay, or vice versa. I wholeheartedly agree that the final choice seemed very limiting and made the advertisement of 'multiple endings based on choices' seem rediculous, however, the ending was broadcast from the very beginning. I believe that a bad ending doesnt necessarily ruin an amazing game like this. The hand painted visuals are amazing, and I love how Max comments on every little thing, sitting down and reading the journal really allows you to get in her head. Also, the soundtrack was incredibly suiting and the rich story of (being an introvert myself) such a relatable person made me truly love the game. The last episode was a let down, but I wont let it ruin such an amazing game for me, after all, I played Mass Effect 3 ;)  All in all, this game is a must buy, so if you actually took the time to read this, buy it, you WILL NOT regret it, you may cry your heart out though, I am honestly thrilled they are making a second season of this.

Well I finished Life is strange. Its really good. Its a really powerful story that engages you in a way no other medium can. I would highly recommend it to anybody. It takes the idea that if a butterfly flaps its wing it could lead to a giant tornado a few months later and uses it to portray many aspects of raw human emotion through the eyes of an 'average' teenage girl.  In the description of the game it is said to 'revolutionise story based choice and consequence games.'. I would not say it revolutionized the genre but rather interpreted it differently. There is a very narrow field of choice of words. In telltale games (Walking Dead, Tales from the Borderlands) there are usually multiple tones of speech (sarcasm, polite, rude, brash, etc) that are all equivalent in how they effect the story. This lets you choose the way your character acts to others which I think is engaging because you can majorly effect the characterization of the main playable character. That being said it may make sense to narrow characterization with Life is Strage because it focuses your choices elsewhere. To me it seems like there are close to 0 choices you make that effect the game's plot deeply. Every player will see all the same scenes with varying character interations. There are small little actions and puzzles that you can perform, or dialouge choices that you make that will change how the characters treat you in conversation but that is as far as it goes. I am not saying this is bad; in fact this makes you focus more on the emotions of characters and the way they think rather than focusing on advancing the plot. This is where the choice system shines because it sucessfully makes you feel like you are talking to real emotional people which is very emmersive. That is why I dont hate on the choice system. Its not bad, just different: which is excusable due to the fact that I belive it functions positivly for such an emotional game.   I like the art style and writing. The art is very unique and quite beautiful at points but looks unnatural and weird at some points. The writing is very High school but is betrayed by the lackluster performance on some of the actors parts. That is not to say it isn't good acting, just not FANTASTIC. The characters are written so belivably and with a lot of intention, but the greatness of the writing didn't stop with characters. The plot is very detailed (albeit there may be sone time travel logic errors) and you can tell there was a lot of thought put into every moment of the game. The use of symbolism in refernece to the butterfly effect is one of the cherries on the top that the excellent writing team put in.  The gameplay is supprisingly varied. I expected to be able to sit back and make some decissions and quickly hit buttons for quick time events like what I was used to with many of these types of games, but I was genuinly supprised to see a wide variety of puzzles integrated into each scene. rather than a quick time event you would get a time travel puzzle. There are also sections where you get a special little mini-game-puzzles to switch things up and advance the plot in an engaging was that didn't require spamming keys.  9.5/10

After two complete playthroughs of this game, I can honestly say this is one of the best games I have ever played. It doesn't have intense gameplay and awesome mechanics. It doesn't have mech-suits or guns or war. It doesn't have stealth or an open-world. But what it does have, is one of the most   kick ♥♥♥   choice-based story-lines I have ever seen, played or heard of. Seriously, this ♥♥♥♥ blows TellTale out of the water and makes their Walking Dead games look like child's play.  Firstly, do not buy this game if you don't understand what you're buying. You are buying a visual/interactive novel, with a branching storyline based on in-game choices. There are no guns. There is no army trying to kill you. Yes, you will walk a lot. Yes it is an   experience   rather than a open-world RPG or an action-adventure shooter. So don't come back to the reviews after you buy it and ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan and call it a 'walking simulator'. You knew what you were buying, and if you didn't, who the hell can you blame but yourself. Now that that's covered...  I mentioned this game is better than the popular games from TellTale. I say this as someone who owns and has played the Walking Dead games from them. While those are good games, in terms of choice-based impact on the story and actual meaningful content from the game itself, it'd be damn hard to somehow do better than Life Is Strange. Every single choice you make has a consequence (like real life almost!   whaddya know...  ). You forget to water that damn plant in your dorm? It might die. Water it too much? It might die. Should you warn that girl that she's about to get hit with a football? Or not? Do you help your friend confront her step-father about her Marijuana? Or not?  Every one of these choices has an impact on the game and the story it is telling, and believe me, you can definitely regret some of the decisions you make in the game.  The plot of Life Is Strange does a very good job of keeping you on your toes at all times. There are plenty of plot twists to be had and characters with very, very good development, and you have an effect on how that all plays out. You can befriend certain characters or be their enemy, that's up to you. You choose what crowd you hang out with and how you treat people. The story itself will obviously follow a set path, so you will have to make choices that you would argue you wouldn't really have to make, but that's a bit of the beauty of the game.  So the character development is good, the choice-based story progression is good, the plot twists and plot itself is good, what else is good? The art style is just amazing for the game. Not glamorous, but definitely nice and crisp and inviting. The voice acting. It is   phenomenal  . Seriously. Some of the best.  All in all, this game is designed to be about the story it tells, and while I won't spoil anything for anyone, I can say there are plenty of plot twists, choices you don't want to make, and the game does a great job of really making you   connect   with not just the main, important-to-plot-progression characters, but also the auxillary characters there to bring life to the world they created.  While I'm never surprised when Square Enix publishes a quality game with a quality story, this developer has certainly shined under their influence. Dontnod's only other game was Remember Me. A game with fairly mediocre/positive reviews. In this game, they have shown what they are capable in crafting for an audience. And they hit a home run.

Incredible. I could not stop playing, and completed it in one go...it couldn't be helped.  Life is Strange is one of the best games, particularly RPG's, I've played in YEARS.  Admittedly, I was skeptical at first. Don't let the bright, cheerful graphics and perceived age group fool you. Before reading into it and giving it a chance, I made the mistake of letting myself believe this game was only intended for a pretty young target audience. I was sorely mistaken, and found this out the hard way as some very dark subject matter slowly began to reveal itself as I progressed.  This game caused SUCH an emotional rollercoaster, and I found myself experiencing a full spectrum of emotions throughout the story. It's so well written that it's difficult not to become invested in many of the characters, and the thought of losing them can be stressful at times. For me, personally, that's a major characteristic of top-notch storytelling. Knowing your choices will directly affect the past, present and future makes it quite difficult to come to conclusions, and you're often forced to sit for a moment (or two...or three) to look at the situation from a logical standpoint. You're forced to take past events into consideration, while trying to remember who did what/who deserves what, all while playing detective. It was quite the brain exercise!  That said, it wasn't perfect, but no game is, nor can it be (imo). You have to be able to ignore some pretty cheesy teenage dialogue at times, firstly. Some of the puzzles were a bit tedious/frustrating and took up a pretty hefty chunk of time to complete, and I was a little unimpressed with the seemingly limited options when it came to the final choice. It was also VERY open-ended with a few plot holes, and I feel like I was left without full closure, but I do understand why, from a developer's perspective.   All in all, I'm so glad I finally caved and gave Life is Strange a chance. It was a unique and incredibly addicting trip through another world, and I can't wait for Season 2. Highly recommend.

This was one of the realest games I have ever played in my life. I can't say that I have never cried in a game (for example: heavy rain, beyond two souls), but this one pushed my emotions. I've never played a game that made me second guess every action I did. I never played a game that made me want to rewind so many times to change the decision I made to later only rewind to change it again.   Nothing I decided seemed good enough, nothing I picked ever seemed like the right choice. It's a game that makes you realize how much our choices affect not only our lives but the lives around us. Some of the choices in the game are so hard to choose from.. making you realize that some choices may or may not be the right choice but might not be wrong either. Then there were times when the choice was so easy, that of course we'll decide the right action because it's obviously the best one like deciding whether or not to let your classmate get hit in the face with a football. For me, the answer is to NOT let her get hit.  I HIGHLY recommend getting this game. It doesn't take any skill to play, it just takes someone who's okay at making hard choices and is able to handle the outcome. I promise you, you won't regret it.. but hey, if you do - maybe you can rewind time and never purchase the game in the first place. Stranger things have happened.

I picked it up thinking it was going to be a great game. I was not only not dissapointed, but even still blown away by everything in it. everything from the emotional rollercoaster that is the story, to absolutely beautiful backgrounds and areas that really do seem just as alive as you would think. a bustling hallway really feels slightly but never actually crowded. a middle of the night park area really feels empty and lonely. this game just absolutely nails the atmosphere aspect of games perfectly. something that is really cool about it though, is the fact that they really did there homework on just how places look in a videogame. how people respond. everything in the game is spot on in the sense that not once will it leave you scratching your head going 'that just isn't even possible' some of the story points may seem a little unlikely, but never impossible. This is quite possibly going to become the new benchmark for story driven games, and for good reason. 10 out of 10 emotional roller coasters, would ride again.

An engrossing, emotional rollercoaster of a game!   When was the last time you played a game that really made you think about the things that mattered to you? Your loved ones, family, friendships. As the credits rolled for the last time, i cant help but feel as if i have said goodbye to a best friend. I have not been this emotionally invested in any game since Mass Effect. If you are even a little interested in getting this game, JUST GET IT ALREADY.   Life is Strange came out of nowhere in 2015, but it is certainly here to stay. I will mention very little of the story here, since i believe you really have to experience it, as well as its surprises for yourself. You play as Max Caulfield, a student studying photographer who one day discovers she can rewind time, and begins to uncover the secrets lurking in Arcadia Bay.  And MAN what a ride this is! Brimming with mystery, and time travel fun, LiS really captures what it is like to be a teenager. Sure some of the lines might sound awkward but for the most part, it feels very true to life! Voice acting is also uniformly strong and given plenty of personality which makes it a joy to get to know the cast. Without spoiling anything, i can say that i enjoyed the game throughout, and the ending felt right.   You'll laugh, cry, hate some characters and love others. This is a fantastic game that stays with you long after the credits roll, and i wish more games were as artistically made as this!

It's an immersive, episodic-choices matter, story-rich game that has a breath-taking atmosphere which takes you on a journey through the narrative view of Maxine Caulfield. You reunite with your best friend Chloe and go on adventures as you learn about your new powers to rewind time. Eventually, you are faced with many challenges as you progress through the game. Each choice you make will affect the game and those around you.  Review: It has many of its moments where you may face dilemma (and some sad moments where you burst out crying like a little girl) but that is just what makes this game amazing. In my opinion, this may have yet been one of the most stunning games I have ever played. You get immersed in the game and establish a connection with the characters, Max and Chloe, and learn about their story. Don't forget the artwork and soundtrack. Art may not be loved by some, but I for one think it's outstanding. It gives off its own sense of unique-ness(?). And don't get me started on the soundtrack. I, personally, like the atmospheric music and the songs that they play throughout the whole game. Especially, Obstacles by Syd Matters. The ending,   you guys know which ending   literally made me cry because it was... well, sad for one, but also it also makes you understand the emotions of the characters question if we were able to do that ourselves. REAL SPOILER-ISH:   All the memories they had with each other is all erased but only remembered by Max.   No, I am not an expert at reviewing or analysing games for that matter, but it still shouldn't stop you from playing this game. Overall, I give this game a 10/10.

SPOILERS, OBVIOUSLY   First, allow me to say that I actually enjoyed the ending. It all makes sense when Choles implores Max to trade her for the town, saying that the week she had with Max was the best parting gift she could ever recieve. After roughly 40 hours' play on all XBOX One, PS4 and PC, the storm is about to take away the Arcadia Bay as Max, Chole, and ultimately the players know it, and you have one choice to make--Bay or Bae. Woe follows whichever one you choose. The game has been billed as a game where choices matter, but this is perhaps the only one that does, since whatever choice you have made earlier in the game doesn't affect anything regarding how the finale is going to play out at this point. I do understand the frustration many of you have here, but I would like to argue that it kind of mirrors the way we make choices, in that although we make all sorts of choices with regards to the nitty gritty or something slightly more important, where different ones land you in different places in life, some favor you and some not, when it all comes down to the important one of which you have the say, you follow your heart in spite of whatever choices you have made before. Sure, Life is Strange is a heart-throbbing and tear-jerking ride that sometimes leaves more to be desired of, but after all, life IS strange, and I'm grateful the game recognizes that.  Life Is Strange also offers a fantastic playlist of Indie tracks that you will fall in love with instantly. Often I just sit back and do nothing but play the songs on Chole's stereo. I can't parise the idyllic, postcard perfect set and immaculate camerawork more becuase almost each screenshot is wallpaper-ready. Along with a very laid-back pace that sinks in your bone and well-written characters you will get to love, hate, understand, empathize, and sympathize, the game sets a good example for tonal integrity in video games. Again, kudos to the creators.  So, if you are fed up with routinely repetitive first-person shooters and want a tatse of something more 'human,' this is the 20 bucks that will be very well spent. It's one of my best spent 20 buck notes anyway.

Life Is Strange is the most beautifully and dreamily artistically designed story-based game I have ever played in my life, and parallel universe me thinks so too!  Life Is Strange is emotion provoking and made me laugh, cry and had my heart pounding throughout all five episodes.  The characterisation and relationship developments between Max and the town members of Arcadia Bay feel so real and made the final choice genuinely agonising.  Never again will I let anyone tell me that gaming is a waste of time. Life Is Strange is a deeply scientific, poetic and theorietical game that will make you come away feeling more knowledgeable than when you started playing. Since playing Life Is Strange I have learned about and researched into: Chaos Theory, The Lorenz Attractor/ Butterfly Effect, Multiverse Theory, Black Hole Theory, Cause and Effect and much much more; making Life Is Strange a game that stays with you even when you aren't playing the game. The storytelling and plot is imperfect due to the game development being rushed, but I personally prefer it this way; because the thing I love most about Life Is Strange are the exciting, interesting and eye-opening fan theories and online discussions. The game is full of ambiguity and makes you think in creative ways about unanswered questions existing within the game.  Life Is Strange also features a beautifully well chosen and atmospheric soundtrack that I immediately downloaded onto my IPod in order to continue the atmospheric mood throughout the rest of my day.  Life Is Strange is a gaming experience that will stay with me for the rest of my life for all the above reasons and the underlying dark themes and unexpected plot- twists that will play on your mind long after you finish playing  I would recommend Life Is Strange to absolutely anyone, and it makes me especially happy that I have found ambiguious representation of my sexuality within such an amazing game. :)

Life Is Strange 4/5:  Telltale style game; featuring actual gameplay... We can only hope that Telltale will remember that next time they develop a new title.   This is a game equivalent of a crowdpleasing indie movie at Sundance festival. Most will really like it, but only a few will love it with all their hearts, because sometimes it is just trying too hard for it´s own good. Nevertheless, it has by all means an exceptionally strong character driven story, which isn´t afraid of mature „indie“ themes. It also fittingly decapitates that specific 'coming of age' period in life; the problems (or 'problems'?) of young adults in high school.   Not interesting enough for your taste? OK, so there is a twist to this formula, because you have the ability to bend time and space! Don´t be alarmed, ' Oh God, what a unnecesary gimmick ', and let me correct you, because in this case, it isn´t gimmick by any stretch of the imagination. On the contrary it´s a core mechanic around which whole game(play) and experience is built. It´s not used just for action purposes ' as odd duck from the art class saved the world ', but mostly for everyday situations, where you can watch 'what would happen if...' In later episodes there is indisputably more to it, but it´s hard to address it without spoiling anything so I will abandon this with statement 'developers bloody well knew what they do' and that they´re obviously inspired by Donnie Darko, David Lynch, original Twilight Zone, Blue Is the Warmest Color, Butterfly Effect etc. and they are not afraid to show it through countless easter eggs (some are too much 'in your face', but many are quite clever and well hidden).   Aesthetics (not mediocre graphics) are top notch, music is appropriately chosen, voice acting is mostly fitting (but lip sync is almost nonexistent) and only two bigger issues are incoherent pacing and that time to time, there are some paper rustling dialogues.    As a result we have moving and atmospheric (nostalgia and melancholy) game with strong (main) characters. Indisputably not for everyone, but everybody should at least give it a try. And it´s not ' just a regular TV show in disguise of a generic episodic game ', because this is ' as good as a quality TV cabel show with game elements “ and so it´s in game industry its own unique thing.

After playing episode 1 of this, I can definitely say this game was made with a lot of love from its developers. The world of Arcadia Bay is very well realized, the characters are believable and the mechanic of Max's powers is intertwined with the game in a way that feels natural once you get the hang of it.  It's like someone noticed the practice of 'save-scumming', ie, reloading a save in a game whenever you get an adverse outcome from doing something, and said, 'hey, let's make that the character's *actual power*'. On a meta level, it's pretty amusing, and it provides for a well balanced power - while Max can fix obvious mistakes, the limit on how far back she can go to change time means she can't always foresee the larger complications of her choices.  The main character herself is adorkable and thoroughly believable as a protagonist. She does second-guess every single major decision no matter what she chooses, but when you have the power to retry something as many times as you want trying to get it 'right', wouldn't you?  Cons: * It took me an embarassingly long time to figure out the 'click and drag' action mechanic. Maybe I just needed more coffee? * The game goes way too far with having a literal popup saying 'THIS ACTION WILL HAVE CONSEQUENCES!!!' at major decision points. If I carelessly leave evidence while searching someone's secret files, or rat out the school's richest kid to the authorities, I shouldn't need the game to tell me that this may come back to haunt me. It's a good thing to have a game where your choices impact the story in meaningful ways, but 'show me, don't tell me' applies. An option to turn this off would greatly improve the game. * The lip synch of the character models can be a little jarring if you pay too much attention to it. Which isn't helped by me pointing it out. But there it is.

Life Is Strange is a beautiful, well-made game. Unlike other adventures, you will not only be annoyed by having to choose one action during a specific situation but by being able to watch at least the immediate results of every action in that situation and still have to choose one. I must have replayed some conversations a dozen times or more trying to decide which one I'd prefer. All of that packed into gorgeous graphics and a lovely soundtrack. I'll probably start a second play-through even today, just so I can see how some early decisions influence the decision tree later on. And of course I'll have to find the hidden opportunities to take photographs during the game.  The only thing I was and, at least in part, am still angry about is one inconsistency. At one point early in the game, you're told that if you take an object and then rewind, you keep that object. Later, you have the choice to either take a picture or intervene. Being the smartass that I am, I took the picture, rewound and intervened, only to find out later that altering my choice removed the taken picture from my inventory.  If you do like adventure games with interesting ideas, go ahead and buy all episodes at once. If you're not sure about it, at least give the first one a try. If you don't like adventures, why are you reading this?
