'Life Is Strange'   is a beautifully written interactive story with both pros and cons. I would call it more of an   experience   than a   video game.   I absolutely love the dark yet realistic high school atmosphere.  We meet Max, our high schooler protagonist being thrown into all sorts of teenage drama. After a strange hallucination of a tornado disaster, she realizes she has the power to reverse time; leading to many choices with different outcomes.     The pros:      I think the art style of this game is absolutely gorgeous. I found myself taking many screenshots during cutscenes.    The story really pulls you deep in the game. Players will find at least one character they can relate with, regardless of it being the situation or the emotions.    I love a game that includes details and many things to look at and interact with, and this game is a perfect example.. Looking around in any environment, you can see grafitti, classmates to interact with, and photos to take.    Replayability with slightly different outcomes and details you may have not noticed on your first playthrough of a episode, although you probably will not play through it more than two or three times.     The technical cons:      Occasionally I would encounter minor glitches with the rewind control, such as the characters becoming frozen in a cutscene and I would enter free roam as if it was over. During these experiences I would have to reload from a checkpoint and watch the entire cutscene over again without the option to fast forward.    Lipsyncing would lag behind the audio, ruining the experience a bit.    I would sometimes have the audio becoming jittery, although video played fine.      All around issues:      I noticed that sometimes characters would have the same reaction no matter what you said to them. I found this irritating as I would rewind to choose a different answer to see what happens, and it was a waste of time. Having extra choices was misleading.    When first playing the game, I got a bit worried that something bad would happen after every choice because of the 'this action will have consequences' message. It took me a while to realize that message appeared no matter what.     I highly reccomend this game, as I throughly enjoyed both episodes 1 & 2 and am eager to continue with this experience.

The thing I said when the game booted was, 'That's beautiful.' And that pretty much describes episode one. The artistic design is spot on, everything looks beautiful as you explore the story. The mechanics work cleverly so that a fail state is impossible and it makes you feel a sense of accomplishment when you figure out the puzzles. Every character feels different, even if they are cliched, but that works for the title. I quickly can to be deeply invested into all the characters to the point where I made choices based solely on helping them rather than thinking about the wide reaching effects of my choices. I can't wait to see the rest of the series. However I will say that this game may be priced a little high condsidering other games of similar length. If the other episodes are of similar length to the first then I would expect to finish in a few hours at most. But I feel the quality of the story is more than good enough to warrant the price.  tl;dr A beautiful game for people who like story, art, and clever use of a single mechanic.

Once in a while the game industry shows us that there is still space for gentle and poetic narratives, that gaming isnt all about blood, explosions and violence: it is, of course, a field that requires fantasy - real life is often dull, so, playing any sort of video game is, in a way, a retreat from this world to a more vivid and interesting one.  Still, this game tells the tale of a youngster, dealing with growing up, ostracism, loneliness, facing dreams about what life could be and the terrible fear of the ever dream-crushing reality. We've been there. Some of us are still dealing with it. Some will never leave this painfull stage of life. But Maxine can rewind time and, by doing so, she can change the course of her own history and that of those around her. Learning to say the right thing in the right time, and gaining infinite opportunities to try and try again and to go on, not only knowing that she did the best she could, but knowing at least the immediate the results of the choice she chose not to make. That bit of fantasy is what defines the strangeness in 'Life is Strange'. without it, the title would be, perhaps, just real every-day dull life.

I played the first episode of Life is Strange, and I want more.  I just picked it up off the Steam sale for two dollars because, hey, might as well give it a shot, and the world the game thrusted me into was pretty damn interesting. The story is pretty catching. I like how they incorporated time powers. In a way, it’s pretty much a rewind button that you can use in case something doesn’t go as planned. But in another way, it’s a way to see how everything plays out before you make a choice. Time rewinding or not, you’re still stuck with one option, and I like how they made the choices have plenty of impacts, and the subtle, long-term, implications of your actions.  If I were to criticize it, I’d say that the protagonist (and a large degree of the cast for that matter) is rather… bland. They have their own dimensions and story, but none of them really stand out. Just the usual high-school tropes (Introverted loner, ♥♥♥♥♥y rich girl, punk rebel, jackass jock… Etc). Stuff you haven’t seen before. Which isn’t a  bad  thing, just that it makes it harder to really - you know - care about the characters. Other times, I’d have to say that the writing/dialogue is wooden, forced, and contrived sometimes (Especially when they use the slangs. Please God no.). And the controls are… pretty awkward (Very hard to get used to). Well, I only played the first episode, so things might be different in the other episodes. Dunno.  I’d still recommend Life is Strange if you want a storybased game. I’m pretty engaged in the story, and I want to see more.  … I just have to wait two weeks before I get money again.

I've played through the second episode. This game is amazing. It's the closest I can think of of a game being a TV series. It gives me a very strong vibe of Buffy the Vampire Slayer or Veronica Mars (if more serious/less comical). Part of this comes through the story and part through the very strong characterizations, but also visually and especially the soundtrack all work together. The setting of a high school was well done, though there were a few oddities, like a high school having dorms.  There are also lots of choices to make, some of which you will realize when they're presented to you, and some only after you've made the choice - a notification will tell you that the decision you made will have consequences. It isn't entirely clear what those consequences will be, but from what I can tell, some are minor but not all are, though you might not see the consequence for a while.  Pros: -Solid story -Great characterizations -Visual quality -Audio quality -Lots of options -For the most part, puzzles seamlessly fit in with the story and don't seem like puzzles.  Cons: -Theres only one save that autosaves. Mostly this is an annoyance for completionists (since you cant just save at every decision, you would largely have to replay the entire episode to make a different decision, apart from the last decision made. -The lip sync doesn't match (IIUC, it's because the game was done in French first?). I honestly didn't notice this until after playing the first episode and having it pointed out to me there was a lipsync problem. -puzzles are mostly fairly easy (if you're looking for a puzzle game).

So far, so good. The first episode created a great base for the story to play out. It showed us the characters, told us their stories and prepared us for what's to come. Life is Strange™ is a great game and I think everybody who likes to see the world through eyes of another should try it.   24.03.2015 UPDATE

Nice game, it is a great slow-paced deviation from today's action-packed CoD and its likes.  In an adventure game, the three pillars are story, puzzles and characters. - The story is interesting and involving, and has its expectedly unexpected turns. Although, the story is again rather slow-paced, which fits the game perfectly - you just don't have 24/7 adrenaline-pumping action as a teenager, after all. - The puzzles are not as complex as one might be used to. Most of the time the solution is just a few feet or a few clicks away, nothing bend-your-head-around. Might be less of a challenge for adventure veterans, but again, it fits the game. - The characters are well done, complete with usual high-school drama and finding yourself. So far, none have had this one 'I will remember this one even in 10 years'-quality, but let's see about this in 10 years.  tl;dr: Good game, maybe not blockbuster of the year, but definitely worth a go.

Life is Strange is a fantastic, well-written story in the point of view of an ordinary 18 year old adult girl named Max who is in an art class at Blackwell Academy, then strangely learns that she has a vision of a tornado soon to wreck the town of Arcadia Bay, also with the ability to turn back time for several occasions as the story-driven experience unfolds. All of the characters.. every one of them.. their backstories, their 'character-build' were just so very well done, especially Max's character! Nothing amazes me more than the beautiful art-style that this game is presented in, the characters have such emotion on them.. you can see their disappointment, you can see their pain and suffering, YOU CAN SEE THEIR REACTIONS TO EVERYTHING EVERYONE DOES.. And man, don't get me all over about the outstanding soundtrack for this game.. god it was so well-composed, and fits every single emotional scene in this game!! Will I recommend this game? I genuinely love this game. I just finished Episode 2 and it affected me as much as Episode 1 did. I've seen this described as Gone Home meets The Walking Dead but I feel like that doesn't do this game justice (and I really liked both of those games). Life is Strange follows the story of Max Caufield, an 18 year old woman who is exeperiencing a lot of upheaval in her life and gains the ability to (limitedly) rewind time. While the rewind time mechanic has been used in a number of games for combat benefit, I never considered it being employed to explore alternate dialogue and decision branches within the context of the story. It's pretty brilliant. I was initially concerned that the characters were going to be one dimensional, but even by the end of the second episode, development can be spotted, even in some of the side characters. I cannot recommend this game enough. If you are remotely on the fence, just buy the first episode for the 5 bucks, try it and then buy the rest of the episodes as soon as you finish it. I've purchased the first episode for several of my friends, knowing they will fall in love with it as well.

[Played LiS thoroughly off-Steam: please don't mind listed playtime.]  Feigning the mundane maturing of a young adult discovering the value in second opportunity for the choices in everyday dialogue and relationships, Life is Strange suddenly graduates to responsibility and flourishes to capture its own identity, leaving its perfectly-imperfect imprint upon this growing interactive cinema genre. It transforms into a journey about people: their flaws, fears, regrets, and insecurities--and shows you how they can mesh together as a special masterpiece about how life can be strange.  DONTNOD's pioneer foray accomplishes its storytelling with powerful nostalgia in a direction that feels organically improvised--chaotic akin to life--with excellent sound and music assets, genuine and interesting atmosphere, uniquely immersive aesthetics style, distinct voice acting, and decision consequences that mean and matter more than most comparable games. These individual elements fall to form a deep empathetic experience that can leave you emotionally exhausted, and amazed how it managed to accomplish that.   I'm an ethusiast gamer with a high mental guard, and since childhood FPS and RTS have reigned over as my favourite genres. After these three years of The Walking Dead coming into spotlight and recently experiencing Life is Strange however, interactive cinema has become a truly unique treasure that I am humbly grateful for as a format that pushes and pulls deep intrinsic feelings far more effectively than any other. It was weeks since finishing could I finally move on from the emotional void caused by this game, but steadfast in appreciation that I had the chance to experience the culmination of the aggregate talent, trust in eventual success, and tremendous time investment to accomplish what so few even attempt to do within this industry, let alone succeed with.  This isn't a perfect game; there are significant early episode lip sync issues, some relatively low resolution textures, possible subjective disbelief in the cast of diverse characters, a few design gaffs such as a bottle collection sequence, and what might be a disappointing denoument leading to an imaginative conclusion, but it's still worth every minute of your time. Life is Strange has made me even more hopeful about this genre's future, and it's undoubtedly my best experience of 2015 by a wide margin.  Spending time on this review is my closure to Max and her story, and it's fair time to let go;   so,    Thank you for this experience, DONTNOD.

One thing that I should point out before you all consider this review - these types of games are a niche in terms of the audience that will find this game worth buying. The story in Life is Strange is something that you take in over time, with the majority of the gameplay essentially being walking, jogging and time manipulation. There is no real combat or 'enemies', so to speak. Rather, it explores the various relationships and teenage troubles evident throughout the game -revolving around its (relatively elaborate) story.   BASIC GAME STORY PREMISE  A teenage girl, Maxine 'Max' Caulfield, has recently moved towns so that she may take up photography classes at Blackwell Academy. During class, she has a vision where a future tornado threatens town. She wakes up puzzled as to what just happened, unsure of what to do. Believing that she's just had a weird day, Max travels to the Girl's bathroom to calm herself down. A butterfly enters the bathroom, intriguing Max, and she follows it around the corner where she takes a photo of it. After, a boy walks in closely followed in by another girl. They argue and the girl is shot. As the girl falls, Max shouts out with her hand raised - only for time to reverse as she ends up back in her photography class. With a sudden realization of what happened, she is determined to save the girl in the bathroom - a fatal decision which essentially messes with the time-space continuum for better or for worse.  ABOUT LIFE IS STRANGE  Life is Strange is an episodic series, spanning 5 different episodes, exploring the mystery of Max's own time manipulative abilities as she tries to find out what happened to a girl that seemingly disappeared from school - Rachel Amber. Max's life essentially revolves around her daily life in Arcadia Bay and her mission throughout Blackwell Academy to find out what happened to Rachel Amber. Throughout the game, you explore the entirety of Blackwell Academy, in addition to memorable places in Arcadia Bay including food bars, beaches, farms and forest junkyards.   The different episodes all explore particular events in the game (hopefully limited spoilers):  Episode 1 - The mystery behind Max's time manipulation abilities and her own basic relationships with other students at Blackwell Academy Episode 2 - Max explores some troubles relating to a student, Kate Marsh, who is assumed to have been drugged at a party. Episode 3 - Max and her best friend break into Blackwell Academy's offices at night to investigate the disappearance of Rachel Amber Episode 4 - Max explores an alternate reality she had caused by time manipulation, relating to the past events of her own best friend. She flips back and forth between different realities, hopeful that she can avoid the impending destruction of her town. Episode 5 - Max enters a nightmare after being captured, flipping between alternate realities, as the fate of the town and her friends lie in her hands.  VALUE  Life is Strange costs US$5.00 for Episode 1, with the 'Season Pass' (the remaining episodes) being $15.00. The entirety of Life is Strange costs $20.00. All episodes have been released - Episode 5 having released around a month prior to the time I wrote this review. I highly recommend this game to anyone that is interested in time manipulation revolving around teenage girls and their lives in school.

This will be a long review and this will feature SPOILERS from both episodes, so be warned.  When I first saw Life is Strange's reveal trailer, I wasn't impressed. I thought of it at first as a Telltale ripoff, just Square Enix trying to cash in on episodic games. When all the reviews came out, I decided 'what the heck, it's only $5'. I played it through and my opinion of it was turned completely upside down. This game is awesome on so many levels.  In this game, you play as Max Caulfield, an ordinary photography geek who is somehow given time travel powers. First off, the concept of the game is awesome, especially with a female lead. The soundtrack is amazing and it fits perfectly with the indie style of the game. The graphics aren't the best, but to me that's not really the focus. The focus is on the characters throughout the game and how they make you feel that you care about them and what happens to them, especially Kate Marsh, a student who is focused on in the first two episodes. The choices you make in the first and second episode will affect how she views you and this will have a significant impact on the game, or at least this episode. This game is extremely heavy and you may get emotional and feel differently about certain things after finishing it. Just a warning.   There are cons to the game, but I can easily get over them. Some may not, so this game may not be for you. First off, the lip syncing is pretty much non-existent. There are some points it matches up, but most of the time, it doesn't. This bothered me at first, but now I don't notice it. Second is the dialouge. A lot of people have trouble with the dialouge, saying that A) It doesn't fit what actual teenagers would say, or B) The dialouge doesn't fit the character. There are some points in the game where you cringe, more in the first than the second for me, personally, when you hear some characters talk. However, that really doesn't affect me much because I want to see this adventure, Max's and mine, continue. It's not perfect, but for me, this is probably the best game released in 2015 that I've gotten this year. If you liked Telltale's games, there's a good chance you'll love this; if you're skeptical, just buy the first episode for five bucks; you more than likely won't regret it.

N.B: This review was written after completing Episode 4 of 5.  Headline summary: If you like story, characters and mystery, buy this game.  Full Review: This game is definitely worth a look if you value stories with a feeling of mystery and nostalgia. The art style is compelling, if a little lacking in detail (which sometimes makes it hard to tell the age of characters etc.). The controls are a little frustrating, particularly when trying to get the optimal angle for those optional photos.  The choice system presents some genuine dilemmas. There are situations when the stress of not having enough information, coupled with the compelling nature of the characters, gives you a feeling of unrest and immediacy that drives the experience forward. This feeling of unease is cleverly enhanced by the rewind mechanic, which makes you just powerful enough to see the immediate consequences your choices have, whilst not providing you with enough insight to be sure that your final decision was bullet-proof. This is a unique experience in adventure games and to be seriously applauded.  However, other situations have a clear morally optimal option, which - particularly when combined with the rewind mechanic - can make them feel like a choice between the 'right' option and everything else. This is not a serious issue, as most 'optimal' solutions are harder to get, which can make reaching them seem like something of an achievement. Nonetheless, I expect that it will limit replay value for anyone who does not enjoy the feeling of deliberately making the 'wrong' choice just to see what happens.  The rewind mechanic itself is a very nice touch and extremely well implemented. It enables the game designers to create some interesting and counter-intuitive puzzles, which whilst not particularly complex, add gameplay depth to a predominantly narrative driven experience.  Nonetheless, by far and away the best part of this game is its cast of characters, who even the hardest of hearts will grow to care about. Max is a compelling lead who manages to combine strength of character with self-doubt and teenage awkwardness in a thoroughly believable manner. Without going into too much further detail - no spoilers I promise - the other characters do not fail to disappoint either. Some tend to be a little cliche at times but those with the most screen time have depth and realism.  The voice acting is solid, if not mind-blowing, with some lines being delivered a little flat and mechanically. Nonetheless, the writing is all there and really drives the game along. It is worth spending time just walking around and chatting to people to pick up those little extra hints and easter eggs, which are reminicent of those that made old school adventure games so much fun.

Remember those choose-your-own-adventure books? You know, the books that were like 'To go left go to page 13 and to go right turn to page 28.' And if you chose the wrong adventure, you would just go back and choose the other option and see how that worked out instead? This is that, put into a game and explained with time travel.  So thats awesome, but it keeps going. The music of the game is an amazing collection of indie/folk/postrock. I can't stop listening to it becasue it's so ♥♥♥♥ing good. I didn't even know what that ♥♥♥♥ was before this game. I still listen to Skrillex for ♥♥♥♥s sake. Go into youtube and type in 'Hipster Study Music.' The first result will be an hour long playlist with a blonde smoking in a hoodie. Listen to the ♥♥♥♥. Its chill af bruh.  But really, the best part about this game is the game itself (even though the music is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome). You play as a teenage girl (18), going through the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t of high school, and the drama surrounding her small town in Oregon. How ♥♥♥♥ing dull does that sound, right? Yet I promise you, somehow, it will be the most fun and emotionally gripping experience you've had in a while. If you cry at emotional things, you should buy a box of tissues to go with this game. If you don't cry at anything, this game will still make you tear up and go deep into thought about your own existence.  This game will ♥♥♥♥ you up and teach you things about yourself you didn't think you knew. Buy all 5 episodes at once. You won't want to stop once you start.  1,000,000/10.

Another game that reinforces the idea of ''graphics are not important'' but the story, characters etc. Life is Strange is a game where all choices you make can affect something in the past, present or future. Simple isn't it?. The point that made this game unforgettable and unique: You can reverse time, every choice you make in the game can be reversed, and this is why the game, in my opinion, considered hard to make choices, because you can regret every single word you said. The main story is one of the best i've ever seen, charged with drama, tension and can provoke a variety of feelings on you. The game soundtrack is beautiful, great songs, mostly indie. Personally I love that kind of soundtrack. Life is Strange is divided in episodes as The Walking Dead and Game of Thrones by Telltale games. There are 5 episodes to be precise. Episode 5: Polarized will be released on October 20th. I say it's one of the best games i've ever played and totally worths it. You can buy the first episode then the season pass that contains episodes 2-5, or you can get the complete game with all episodes, it's not that expensive and you'll not regret it. Awesome game.  ''Hella good'' - R4Z0R 10/10
